respondent.name: MICHAEL CHERTOFF, SECRETARY OF HOMELAND SECURITY.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We'll hear argument first this morning in Case 06-1717, Richlin Security Service versus Chertoff. Mr. Wolfman.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Wolfman, what about the cap that's not present in 1988 and is present in EAJA?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Excuse me. The paralegals' rates would also be subject to the -- to the cap.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: They couldn't go above the cap.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: May I just ask on that last point, does the government agree that the paralegals' fees are subject to a cap?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Indeed, would insist.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But they do not agree with the bottom line that they are subject to cap?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- attorney's fees.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But you -- isn't that one of the problems with your argument? Because there is something very strange about capping paralegal fees at the same amount that they would cap a lawyer's fees for, regardless of what that amount is and when they were setting it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: No, I'm looking at it from the perspective of the original enactment on your theory at that moment. These fees were legal fees, were attorney fees, and they were capped at the same amount that a lawyer's time was capped at. And that's just odd.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, agent fees - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I mean, the problem exists whether or not you make paralegal fees attorney's fees, because agent fees are also subject to the same cap.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And agents were paid a good deal less than that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: You began -- and it's not just because of my notepad but because I'm interested - - you told Justice Ginsburg there are two reasons - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- why the government's cap is wrong. And I'm not even sure you finished the first one. What are the two reasons?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But may I ask you this?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Supposing at the time the statute was enacted, paralegals' fees were not generally treated as lawyers' fees, but rather were disbursements, does that make a difference?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I'm sorry. Is your point there that most associates are billed at less than $125 an hour?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Too much money proportionally.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: If -- if paralegal charges are not fees but are other expenses, what would be the standard for determining the rate at which they would be compensable? Would it necessarily be cost under this statute or would it simply be what is reasonable?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: This problem is going to exist anyway, isn't it? I mean, even if you don't cram paralegals into the other expenses, there are going to be other expenses that are in the other expenses.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You're going to have to have this same problem -- and what about the overhead and so forth?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, if -- if it's simply reasonableness -- because I don't see anything in the statute that says that all non-fee expenses are compensable at cost -- if it's simply reasonableness, would it be possible to say that what would be reasonable would be a rate that preserves the ratio between attorneys' fees and paralegal fees that existed at the time when the statute was enacted so that you wouldn't have the problem of attorneys being compensated at the same rate as paralegals?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: No. No. If the ratio -- if lawyers were -- I know that if lawyers were compensated at $125 an hour when this was enacted and paralegals were compensated at $75, then it would be a 2-1 ratio, and you'd preserve that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Am I to understand, you claim that even if they are expenses, they should - - they should be paid for at market rate, don't you?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Wolfman, if there's any discretion in the district judge in setting the amount of the fee, then why wouldn't it be appropriate to say, now there's a cap for the lawyer is $125 an hour, but we know the true market rate for that lawyer is $200? Does it do the same thing with the paralegal? The true market rate is X, and we're going to knock it down so that it will match the knock-down for the lawyer?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But isn't it likely that when Congress said that, it was not thinking of paralegals.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I'm sorry. "Traditionally subsumed in the lawyer's rate," are you suggesting, when this statute was passed, they weren't billed separately to the client?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Of course, that's no loss to the government because when you put it into the lawyer's rate, you hit the ceiling for the lawyer's rate that much sooner.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It seems like that would be

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: I'm sorry. Why wasn't it true in 1980? You simply mean in 1980 the two together wouldn't have gotten as high as the cap?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Assume that our decision will in part drive the market either way, what we do will effect the way paralegals are used, the way billing is done. If that is true, is there some utility in simply following the EAJA so we give a consistent signal to the market and then if Congress wants to change it, it can? I mean - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Rather than follow EAJA, I mean follow 1988, follow Jenkins. Follow Jenkins.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Are there some disutilities from an economic standpoint in having two structures: Jenkins for one kind of cases, EAJA in the other cases as the government wants?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Are there some disadvantages to the system?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But that's -- I saw that analysis. This Act only applies when the government's position is not substantially justified. People are not going to structure their billing arrangements assuming the government's position is not even going to be substantially justified.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: That point makes some assumptions about the relative abilities, say, of junior associates and senior paralegals, and I'm not sure are well founded. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Is that pertinent - - is that pertinent on the cap questions we've been discussing too? I mean, if you're representing a disabled veteran, is the lawyer typically charging more than $125 an hour?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I would not say no one else, but not everyone else places the importance on legislative history that I do, but I do. And I saw here that the Senate Judiciary Committee considered all these arguments, they wrote a report; and they sided with the government.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And I know it was there, but it doesn't matter to me it was on a bill that was later not passed, and then unless there is something different - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- for that reason, because in my own mind I'm thinking there were a group of people on the committee, they went through the issue, they reflected views of their principles, they work it out, and unless something changed that makes me think that isn't the working out of it, I would put a lot of weight on it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And now you're going to tell me what there is, I hope.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: And of course they may mean -- may have meant costs to the client.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Counsel. Mr. Yang.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: You say the relevant one was of course on a legislation that wasn't passed, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What is cost? Could you -- one could say I'm going to look at the Internet and come up with $35 dollars an hour, or you could say in the case of a paralegal there is a part of the overhead, there is the fringe benefits -- so just giving the hourly rate is deceptive of what the actual cost is to the law firm, because the law firm has to add on to determine what in fact it's paying for the paralegal, the fringe benefits and part of the overhead.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well and it might be quite different for private practitioner. Your benefits for health care will probably cost you a lot less than private practice and doesn't that make the paralegal fees quite different than the other items of expenses that are listed? You know, expert witnesses, you get a bill, that's how much it costs the lawyer. Studies, analysis, engineering reports, you don't have to figure overhead benefits with respect to any of those. All of a sudden you throw in another item, paralegal costs, you put those under costs, and now you've got to go through this elaborate calculation that is going to be not worth it, almost, for a typical firm representing a small client.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, in most firms an engineering report would be outside the - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: It seems to me the question is a valid one, that you're running away from the question.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And I'll let you answer. It suggests this further inquiry. Suppose that a solo practitioner knows that a paralegal in another firm is very good at this and he asks the other lawyer, may I use your paralegal, and he just sends that lawyer the bill. What -- how would that be billed under your view?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: They both -- they both apply, they both apply to outside experts.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, but that wasn't Justice Kennedy's question. His was the outsourced paralegal is better at a particular task.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well in that case it would bill the paralegal in the same way it would bill, I take it, the expense of, let's say, having water tested in a pollution case. It would -- it would -- I take it it would bill the client dollar for dollar what it had to pay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: And add - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: They don't add a profit and they don't add a profit on to -- to travel expenses and things like that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: And -- so if that is so, in each case cost means cost to the client, and you're coming up with a new category of expense, which is cost to someone else, and why should there be a subcategory of expense, in which cost does not mean cost to the client when every other category of expense does mean cost to the client?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Because there is a separate provision for fees.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: At this discretion, let me ask this question. Maybe it's the same question Justice Kennedy asked, but I want to be sure of your answer. Suppose you had independent firm of paralegals. I don't know whether the market contains them, but it surely could. A firm that they are all paralegals, and they then bill the law firm at their own hourly rate, and then the law firm in turn bills the client. In that situation, would the market rate of the independent firm of paralegals govern?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Do I understand the government's position that the -- the result would different if a firm uses its own paralegals as opposed to outsourcing?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: No. But under my example they would be paying the market rate for paralegals, and I think you say they could be reimbursed for that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Well, they are not market to make business. I presume the paralegals would charge the going rate.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: I assume that they also charged the market rate.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But again, you're not answering the hypothetical. Let's assume two cases: Case A, you hire an outside paralegal at $85 an hour. He is outside, he is independent. He is just like the expert engineer in the Chief Justice question, $85 an hour. Case two, it's your own paralegal. The prevailing rate for which you charge general clients is $85 an hour. Why should there be a difference?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But under your -- they can't even charge $85 an hour.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I know you said that a few times and you have authority for it, but it seems to me odd if you look at 1988 and if the attorney's fees and costs -- and costs is very limited in the statute in 1920 -- and if you have attorney's fees and other expenses, other expenses is a much larger category than costs within 1988. So I -- I would think that, well, EAJA is the more compensatory because it allows for more items.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Counsel, your - - this question only arises when the position of your client was not substantially justified. Now under those -- and it was designed, to some extent, to penalize you because -- because of that fact. Why should we adopt a construction that, in effect, penalizes the client who has had to face the Federal Government when the Federal Government's position was not substantially justified? They are going to have to pay the paralegal fees at market rates, but they are only goes to get compensation at cost.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: It's kind of a stretch to suggest in a situation where they pass a law that only applies to individuals or small businesses where they put a cap in and so on, that another way that we are going to prevent damage to the fisc was to treat paralegal expenses as costs rather than at market rate. I suspect that was not foremost in their mind.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, it assumes that when they said "costs," that they meant costs to the firm as opposed to costs to the client. And that, I think, is entirely an open question.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Not to belabor the point it meant that the people who drafted the Senate report may have meant that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I don't think it is a problem with legislative history. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I think that the people in Congress who hired their staffs pay attention to what the staffs say in precisely the same way that any other executive - -

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Do we know what the President's view was on that question when he signed the legislation into law, which is what he was required to do before it became law and which he did not do under the prior bill?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Do you know of any other case where we used -- I mean it just gets worse and worse. Do you know any other case where we've used the legislative history of a vetoed bill to determine the meaning of a later bill that was not vetoed?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Good. What is it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: When was that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Never mind. Don't take - - don't waste your time.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I mean that wouldn't be surprising would it, that wouldn't be surprising because you have, in fact, very complex bills that have 14 sections and section of the B bill could have been vetoed -- been vetoed because of problem with Section 14 and repassed without Section 14, in which case the legislative history for the other 13 sections would be highly illuminating as to what they mean.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: The question that I had in respect to this statute is -- is that my impression and here -- I'd like to know how they bill secretary's times. I'd like to know how they bill rent. And my thought is -- and I want to be either verified or told I'm wrong and explain it, that when you have no cap, the lawyer and the client want to shove everything possible into the rubric attorney's fees, including the kitchen sink, if the plumber is there in the kitchen of the law firm. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: That's fine. No problem. There is no other way to get paid for them. But where you have a cap, you should shove everything the other side, if expenses are going to be paid for it, because that cap means that the lawyer will not get his full pay back and therefore, the lower the cap, the more you want to be sure it's covering only that lawyer's time. And everything else goes into expense so that you can pay the lawyer adequately and he will recover his expenses elsewhere. Was that the theory of this bill? Is there any evidence that that was the theory? If you did it that way, would anything get mixed up?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Am I right that when this language first came in -- this is in relation to Justice Breyer's question -- there was no cap? When did the - - when was the cap put on?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: It was.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: It would be a lot of weight to be put on three little words: "Billed at cost." If you just read those words, you could be the costs to the client, the cost to the law firm and then you'd have to go to this further document, the Administrative Conference document, it's rather thin I think.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: May I go back - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: May I go back to the point, because I think you were cut off before you went into the full legislative history. I'm still concerned about the argument that even if they are not fees but rather costs, that the costs should be those that are billed to the client. And you think there is some conclusive answer in the legislative history that that's not the case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Which took place when?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: At that time were they billing paralegal's fees at cost to the client? Was it - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Every expense that's reimbursed at cost has a profit element in it for whoever performed the service.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Business or otherwise.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, maybe this is the same question Justice Breyer asked, but I haven't - - I didn't grasp the answer. Under your system it would make sense for lawyers to charge separately for photocopy services, telephone services, so on because then they are not going to be subject to the attorney fee cap. And they may think, look, the difference between cost and market rate is relatively small; the difference between our hourly rate and $125 is large.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, I'm just saying if we adopt your position, isn't it going to be, I guess, worse for your client because firms will, as I've been told firms sometimes do, charge separately for things at a higher rate than their cost? They will charge higher rate for photocopy services because they try to factor into it overhead and things like than cost.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, I would say - - I would say that it's now traditional for firms to charge, say, more for their photocopy services than it cost them.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But the cap doesn't apply to expenses, does it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: The cap does not apply to reimbursement expenses at cost?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: It seems to me just the opposite just as the Chief Justice suggests. It seems to me you're creating an incentive for the firms to - - to charge as much as they can -- I mean, under market rates for everything under the -- under the time of the lawyer himself.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: No, because other costs reasonably interpret to include overhead. It's not just the paper and the accounting time.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, I think you missed my point. It was even if you're right, 50 cents and they can only charge 15 cents, they have an incentive to separately charge for photocopying, because they get the 15 cents, and otherwise it's going to - - they are going to lose it over the cap if you say no that's part of the attorney's fees.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: When you have a -- you can submit it a letter. I've looked in your brief, I can't find this Jean case that you mentioned on use of veto. I have a certain morbid interest in it. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I'd like to go back to a question that Justice Kennedy asked of Mr. Wolfman. Isn't there -- doesn't it make sense to take a word like "attorney's fees" and like the word "discrimination," we have many different anti-discrimination statutes, but there has been an attempt to give that word "discrimination" the same meaning in all those statutes. And here the term attorney's fees, if it means that includes all of them, in terms of 1988, why not say every time attorney's fees comes up, that's what it's going to mean?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well on that point, does the statute say that all non fee expenses are compensable at cost? Or are you arguing that the work that's done by paralegals is a study or analysis project?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Which is it, is it a study analysis or project? That seems like a strange way of describing it.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Counsel, there are occasions, aren't there, when the government is entitled to attorney's fees?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Do you know how you bill paralegal times -- time in those situations?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: You often don't bill them separately.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Yang. Mr. Wolfman, you have four minutes remaining.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, but I think Justice Breyer is correct, isn't he, that there was no reason for the Senate to sort of redo a report that they had already done on a bill that was substantially identical?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: There was no Senate report because they had done it just the previous year.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Counsel, the case is submitted.
